div.head: Overview
div.p: One of the many epithets of a buddha, and frequently used as a synonym (but perhaps less often than tathāgata).

The English renderings “one who has well gone” or “well-gone one” are approximate, but serviceable if it is understood that they are renderings in English of this specific epithet. It is also acceptable in some cases to leave the term sugata in Sanskrit.

div.head: Etymology and Meaning
div.p: The Sanskrit su means, in general, “good” or “well,” and gata means “gone,” the past passive participle of √gam, “go”; gata here does not denote physical movement as much as changing state, “become.”
In essence, the meaning is “one who has gone well,” in three main senses: (1) excellently, (2) irreversibly, and (3) completely.

These three meanings are outlined in the entry for sugata in the ninth century Drajor Bampo Nyipa (sgra sbyor bam po gnyis pa) Toh 4347 in the Tengyur, vol. sna tshogs, co, F.133.b.3. The sgra sbyor bam po gnyis pa (“Two Fascicles on Lexical Usage”) is the companion work to the Mahāvyutpatti (bye brag tu rtogs par byed pa chen po, or “Great Handbook of Comprehensive Learning,” Toh 4346), both constituting the specifications for the state-sponsored translation work of the early translation period. as follows, to expand on the Mahāvyutpatti’s specified Tibetan rendering, bde bar gshegs pa:

item.p: [A.] Sugata according to one definition means:
śobhanagata sugata surūpavat — “well gone” because he has gone excellently, as in “well formed.”
apunar āvṛtyagata sunaṣṭajvarvat — “well gone” because he has gone irreversibly, as in “an epidemic has been well cleared away.”
yāvad gantavyagamanāt sugata | supūrṇaghaṭavat — “well gone” because he has gone as far as there is to go, as in “the vase has been well filled.”

[B.] According to another definition from the Dharmaskandha: Dharmaskandha here refers not to the sūtra of that name, which contains no mention of sugata, but probably to the *Abhidharmadharmaskandhapādaśāstra, an Abhidharma treatise of the Sarvāstivādin school attributed in the Indian tradition to Śāriputra but in the Chinese tradition to Maudgalyāyana. It was never translated into Tibetan and now exists in full only as a Chinese translation by Xuanzang, and in the form of fragments of a Mūlasarvsāstivardin recension in Sanskrit found in Gilgit.

sugata iti sukhito bhagavān | svargita avyathitadharmmasamanvāgata | tad ucyate sugata” — “because the Blessed One is in wellbeing, and has the wellbeing of the higher realms, and because he is not subject to harm and has the dharmas of the absence of harm, he [can either be said to have] ‘well gone’ or, also, to have ‘attained wellbeing.”
A combination of the former definitions with the latter from the Dharmaskandha was used to designate the [Tibetan rendering] bde bar gshegs pa.

div.p: The three shades of meaning [A. 1–3] of sugata set out in the Drajor Bampo Nyipa entry are found quite widely in the Sanskrit literature.

item.p: To express the sense of “gone/become perfect,” sugata is glossed using phrases such as praśastaṃ gataḥ, śobhanaṃ gataḥ, suṣṭhurūpeṇa gataḥ, etc. When the three main meanings are listed together, this one comes first, perhaps suggesting that this meaning of sugata is the most important.
To express the sense of irreversibility, sugata is glossed as apunarāvṛttyā gataḥ.
To express the sense of “gone/become completely,” sugata is glossed using phrases such as atiśayena gataḥ, niḥśeṣaṃ gataḥ, or suṣṭhugataḥ.

div.p: There are also other interpretive phrases that fall somewhere between the above three interpretations such as nikhilasavāsanāśeṣakleśajñeyāvaraṇāni prahāya gataḥ, meaning “gone having abandoned all the kleśas and cognitive obscurations along with all the habitual tendencies,” or nairātmyadvayamārgeṇa samyag gataḥ, meaning “gone properly on the path of the two [types of] no-self.”

The rendering in Tibetan, bde bar gshegs pa, has led to different interpretations in other languages because bde bar can be taken either adverbially (gone “well” or “easily”), or as a dative (gone “to happiness” or “to bliss”). The adverbial interpretation is closer to the original Sanskrit and conforms to the first part [A.] of the Drajor Bampo Nyipa entry. However, the second part [B.] of that entry (derived from the Dharmaskandha) potentially leads to some blurring of this distinction and supports the dative interpretation, as it seems to refer to the happiness, wellbeing, or bliss to which the Buddha has gone.

The Tibetan rendering bde bar gshegs pa, as decreed in the Mahāvyutpatti, seems to have been universally used. There appear to have been no alternative renderings of the term in Tibetan translations even prior to the Mahāvyutpatti’s establishment.

div.head: Details of Usage
div.p: Sugata is a very widespread epithet for buddha or tathāgata found in a wide variety of genres of literature.
The Buddha Śākyamuni refers to himself as “the tathāgata” but not as “the sugata.” When others talk about him or address him, however, both are used, sometimes even in adjacent sentences.

Sugata is most commonly used alone; when a whole sequence of epithets are used to name or otherwise mention a buddha, tathāgata is more common than sugata. Both sugata and tathāgata do not seem to be used together in the same sequence, with the notable exception of the phrase

p.foreign: de bzhin gshegs pa dgra bcom pa yang dag par rdzogs pa’i sangs rgyas rig pa dang zhabs su ldan pa/ bde bar gshegs pa/ ’jig rten mkhyen pa/ skyes bu ’dul ba’i kha lo sgyur ba bla na med pa/ lha dang mi rnams kyi ston pa/ sangs rgyas bcom ldan ’das de

q.p: “…the thus-gone, worthy, fully and truly awakened buddha, perfect in knowledge and conduct, a blissful one, a knower of the world, an unsurpassed leader of those to be trained, a teacher of gods and humans, that blessed buddha…”

div.p: Whereas tathāgata can be used for buddhas of the past, present, and future, the use of sugata seems to be mainly confined to the past and present—with one exception, perhaps confirming this unwritten rule, in the common phrase about a future buddha “after that sugata has passed away…”.

As a compound, sugatagarbha (bde gshegs snying po) is used as a synonym for buddha-nature at a roughly equal frequency as tathāgatagarbha (de gshegs snying po), with no apparent difference in shades of meaning.

item.p: Sugatas of the Five Families: bde gshegs rigs lnga — mainly in Vajrayāna contexts, the sugatas of the five families: Vairocana for the Sugata (or Buddha) family; Akṣobhya for the Vajra family; Ratnasambhava for the Ratna (Jewel) family; Amitābha for the Padma (Lotus) family; and Amoghasiddhi for the Karma (Activity) family. They are also associated with the five skandhas, five directions, and so forth.
Eight Sugatas: bde gshegs mched brgyad — the eight sugatas of the Medicine Buddha tradition including the Medicine Buddha himself, Bhaiṣajyaguru.
Eight Sugata Stūpas: bde gshegs mchod rten brgyad — the traditional set of eight stūpas built in different places to commemorate different events of the Buddha Śākyamuni’s life.

Thirty-Five Sugatas: bde gshegs so lnga — the thirty-five sugatas invoked in the confession ritual of the “three heaps” (triskandhaka, phung po gsum), although in the text itself (see Toh 68) they are termed tathāgata.
